9.text:
Hello and welcome to this Easy Composites
video tutorial. In this series which is probably

14.text:
the most ambitious we'll ever take on we're
going to be answering the question that we

18.text:
get asked more often than any other, which
is how to make you're own carbon fibre vehicle

22.text:
panels like this car bonnet that you see here.
In the tutorial we're going to be showing

27.text:
you every single step along the way including
making the mould, making the parts, bonding

32.text:
the parts together, trimming and finishing
to enable you to make your own incredibly

37.text:
light, incredibly strong perfectly finished
carbon fibre panels. We really hope you enjoy

43.text:
it. The first step in our process is to take
this original steel bonnet which we're using

52.text:
as our pattern. We're going to add barriers
all the way around the outside of it so that

56.text:
when we make our mould we actually created
a mould with a flange on, and that flange

60.text:
will add stiffness to the mould and it will
also give us plenty of opportunity to position

66.text:
the bagging consumables and things for the
resin process. Before we actually apply any

71.text:
barriers to this part we're just going to
take the opportunity to put down a full background

76.text:
layer of release agent. We're using Easy Lease
which is a chemical release agent and of cause

80.text:
this is what's going to stop the gel coat
from sticking to the part but while we've

84.text:
got the bonnet in this state it's much easier
to ensure that we've got everywhere covered

89.text:
and then we'll probably do another application
later on. Making barriers can be tricky. The

94.text:
technique that we've developed is to use corrugated
signboard for the barriers themselves and

99.text:
the bond those to the underside of the part
using hot melt glue. So the first thing to

103.text:
do is to use masking tape to actually make
a template around the edge of the part and

108.text:
then we'll transfer that onto the signboard
and cut the barriers themselves. So with the

117.text:
masking tape all the way around the edge of
the part it's a case of just marking up where

122.text:
we're actually going to make the barrier pieces
in separate sections and we also at the same

128.text:
time just draw on the angle that we're going
to cut the barrier sections at and finally

134.text:
number them so we can identify them. So we're
going to have a cut line here and a cut line

140.text:
coming off at this angle here. Then this will
all be one piece and we'll have cut lines

149.text:
on the barrier about there. The masking tape
comes off the part extremely easily. So we're

155.text:
just going to start it off and then cut it
into the parts that we've identified, being

161.text:
careful not to rip the tape. So we're transferring
this line here onto the board. We know the

177.text:
angles that we want to make the barriers at.
Once we've marked out all these templates

183.text:
we're just going to cut them out with a sharp
knife and then position them around the outside

187.text:
of 
the part. we're working on the underside of
the bonnet now where we're going to be positioning

201.text:
this barrier. Now the way we're going to do
that is we're going to apply masking tape

205.text:
to the edge on the underside of the bonnet
here and then we're going to be using hot

209.text:
melt glue on the masking tape and then on
the barrier. the reason for the masking tape

213.text:
is so that this barrier is quite easy to remove
when we're done with the process. So we can

218.text:
get started with that with the masking tape.
We've got masking tape all the way along this

230.text:
top edge so now it's time to use hot melt
glue gun we're going to just put a bead of

234.text:
glue all the way along the top edge and then
stick the barrier to it. We've now flipped

246.text:
this bonnet over just before we do the wax
we're actually going to use a release tape

252.text:
to actually just seal these joins, or a breaker
tape and that's just going to prevent again

258.text:
any of the gel coat from running down into
the gap. So we just take the tape and tape

265.text:
the seam and because it's a release tape the
resin and the gel coat won't stick to it.

271.text:
So the next step is to us a yellow filleting
wax to actually create a bead all the way

277.text:
around the edge between the bonnet onto the
flange and what that will do is stops the

282.text:
gel coat from running under and locking in
and also gives us a nice smooth transition

287.text:
so that when we've got the mould the parts
themselves are going to release nicely and

291.text:
they're not going to get caught up or mechanically
locked on this edge. So we've put the filleting

298.text:
wax all the way around the outside now and
you can see from this close up what we want

303.text:
to do is always be sure that when you put
the wax down you've got what's called a draft

307.text:
angle and that's going to mean that when we
remove the part of separate the part and the

312.text:
mould that there's not going to be a mechanically
lock. We're now ready to put the proper coat

319.text:
of release agent onto the bonnet and we're
going to apply two coats of the Easy Lease

323.text:
all the way over the surface of the panel.
Now the filleting wax doesn't requite a release

328.text:
agent and in fact will actually get dragged
off by the release agent if we're not careful

333.text:
so we're not going to apply any release agent
to the wax. We are going to apply the release

337.text:
agent onto the barrier itself just in case
there's any contamination. It is made from

342.text:
polypropylene so it shouldn't stick but just
in case it does we're going to give it a coat

347.text:
over as well. We've now left this a good half
an hour to fully dry off and we're actually

352.text:
going to apply two coats of wax all the way
over the top of this the steel bonnet part.

359.text:
Now usually we wouldn't use a wax on top of
a release agent. A chemical release agent

364.text:
generally works on its own however in the
case of going from a pattern to the mould

370.text:
itself we want to be absolutely sure that
we're not going to have any problems with

374.text:
the release and so having the chemical release
agent and the wax although it's a slightly

379.text:
unusual combination is going to ensure that
we do have no release problems. We're now

384.text:
buffing off the wax having left it about five
or ten minutes and you just really want the

390.text:
lightest possible pressure when you're doing
this just using a micro fibre cloth here and

394.text:
just skimming over the surface and you can
see the shine start to emerge. Right so we've

400.text:
now left the wax to fully harden off which
is roundabout half an hour or something like

405.text:
that and so it's actually time to make the
mould itself. So we're going to be using a

410.text:
very versatile tooling system called Uni-Mould
and the Uni-Mould system comprises a tooling

417.text:
gel coat which is a vinylester tooling coat.
Now the reason we're using vinylester is that

422.text:
that's actually compatible with polyester
resin, vinylester resin but most importantly

428.text:
for us epoxy resin and it will guarantee an
excellent release of the parts out of the

433.text:
mould which you wouldn't get with a normal
polyester gel coat. The Uni-Mould system then

438.text:
uses a coupling coat which is reinforced coupling
coat we actually add a lightweight chopped

444.text:
strand mat in with that which forms the connection
between the tooling gel and then the tooling

451.text:
resin itself. Applying the gel coat now we
can do this in either two thin coats or one

456.text:
thicker coat. We'd be targeting in a single
thick coat of a roundabout 0.8 mm. Now for

465.text:
a bonnet this size we're looking at mixing
up a roundabout 700 grams of gel coat if you

472.text:
mix up too little and you come up short you
can always mix up some more. We're using normal

477.text:
MEKP catalyst and a ratio of about 1.5 to
2 percent. So for 700 grams of the gel coat

485.text:
that would obviously be 14 grams at 2 percent
of the catalyst. Applying the gel coat is

490.text:
totally straightforward covering it and we're
going for that approximately 1 mm which is

495.text:
a reasonably thick application. We've now
allowed this gel coat to cure to the right

500.text:
point. It's certainly very much firmed up
but it's still got a very slight level of

504.text:
tack which is the right point for a gel coat.
So in the Un-Mould system it's now time to

509.text:
add the coupling coat. As we say we've got
a light chopped strand mat, we're using a

514.text:
225 gram here. This is really as heavy as
you would want to go at the coupling coat

520.text:
stage, you could go lighter and we're going
to be wetting this through with the coupling

525.text:
coat. Again this is catalysed at a ratio of
about 1.5 to 2 percent we're going to be catalysing

532.text:
it about 2 percent and we're going to use
a full kilo on this layer. When the coupling

542.text:
coat has been fully catalysed it does actually
change to a darker colour so you can tell

546.text:
it's ready to go. Now when you're working
with he coupling coat it's just like any chopped

553.text:
strand laminating so you apply the resin to
the part first and then drop the glass mat

561.text:
down onto the resin and then wet it through
from above. The light chopped strand provides

567.text:
reinforcement at this early stage but because
its a light mat it's very easy to get it down

572.text:
into the contours of a mould which ensures
that you're not going to have any voids between

577.text:
the gel coat and the main tooling reinforcement
and the coupling coat itself chemically is

584.text:
designed to act as an interface between this
vinylester tooling gel coat and the tooling

589.text:
resin itself. We've now allowed this coupling
coat to cure in our case its taken around

602.text:
three hours and it's very much firm to the
touch but it got a slight tack and that's

606.text:
the right point for us to go on with the main
reinforcement. Now because we're using the

611.text:
Uni-Mould tooling system we're going to be
putting down all of the reinforcement and

615.text:
the resin in one hit. The Uni-Mould tooling
resin is a filled resin system so it's very

622.text:
important to thoroughly mix up the contents
and we'll also give it a quick stir to make

629.text:
sure that any sediment or fillers are thoroughly
mixed in to the resin. With the resin catalysed

635.text:
at between 1 and 2 percent, we've used 2 percent
because it's only a small mould we're then

639.text:
going to apply the resin all the way over
the surface and start building up this chopped

643.text:
strand mat. So we want to work reasonably
quickly and get it all down in one hit. We've

677.text:
now allowed this to cure fully overnight as
you can see the colour of the mould has changed

682.text:
to a lighter shade indicating that the exotherm
has taken place and so we're going to turn

687.text:
the mould over and without removing the bonnet
we're going to look at making the moulding

691.text:
for the inner skin. Okay so we're now going
to remove the temporary barriers that we put

696.text:
in place. And you can see the why we signboard
its released perfectly from the tooling gel

713.text:
coat. we're going to be using the flange from
the upper mould as the flange for the lower

719.text:
mould and so what we're going to do is leave
most of this filleting wax in place but we're

724.text:
just going to ensure that it's nice and smooth
so that its acts again as a fillet between

729.text:
the flange and the inner mould that we're
going to make. So we're looking at the underside

735.text:
of the bonnet now. We've got lots of holes
as you can see that have been cut out, die

740.text:
stamped out of this inner skin we need to
blank all of these of which we'll be using

744.text:
release tape for and we've also got these
studs here that were for the hinge mechanism

751.text:
and the latch at the front. Now because we're
happy to sacrifice the bonnet in this case

755.text:
we're going to grind these off and again grind
the latch mechanism off. If you didn't want

760.text:
to sacrifice the bonnet and you want to keep
it useable then you could blank these off

764.text:
using plasticize or something similar and
then make the mould around them but for simplicity

770.text:
we're just going to grind them off. So applying
the release tape to mask off these holes on

781.text:
the underside of the bonnet. We just pull
the tape tight over the hole and press it

785.text:
down firmly. So where we've ground off this
latch mechanism we're going to tape all the

790.text:
way over this using the release tape. And
the tape should be sufficiently strong that

795.text:
we won't need any other reinforcement over
that area. So we're applying the Easy Lease

802.text:
chemical release agent all the way over the
surface of the inside of this part and very

807.text:
importantly this time round on the flanges
as well. We'll be applying two applications

814.text:
of the chemical release agent and then we'll
be following up with two coats of wax making

819.text:
sure on this occasion that we thoroughly wax
the flange. Where you can see the upper moulding

829.text:
meeting the lower moulding and we've got this
gap here we need to thoroughly fill that with

835.text:
the wax fillet to prevent the tooling coat
from running under there and sticking. So

840.text:
we just put in a large bead of wax and then
smooth it out in just the way we've been doing

844.text:
elsewhere. So if we just take a quick tour
now of what we've done before we put the gel

849.text:
coat on. We've got release tape over all of
the catch mechanisms we've got any interior

857.text:
holes we've filled with release tape and again
we've cut those to be nice and neat. On these

863.text:
areas where we've got a bit of undercut on
the actual steel of the bonnet we've completely

869.text:
filled that with filleting wax as we did with
this awkward corner. And you can also see

874.text:
how we finished that middle edge. Okay so
we've just mixed up a new batch of the tooling

880.text:
gel coat and we're just going to apply this
all the way over the surface of the inside

885.text:
of this mould just like we did on the top
mould. Again we're going for that target 0.8

892.text:
mm thickness which is a reasonably thick brush
application. now that the gel has cured we're

900.text:
just going to put down another coupling coat
exactly as we did before. here again we're

907.text:
using the 225 gram glass but another excellent
option for the coupling coat is something

912.text:
even lighter like a couple of layers of an
80 gram. So the coupling coat has no cured

922.text:
of and it's time for the main reinforcement
again. Just like before we'll be applying

929.text:
all of the reinforcement and the tooling resin
in one session. We'll be using four layers

937.text:
of the 450 gram chopped strand mat. So that's
the underside of this mould finished so we'll

943.text:
allow this to cure fully overnight and then
tomorrow we'll be trimming these and separating

949.text:
them. This mould has fully cured now so we've
marked up a trim line all the way round the

956.text:
edge equally spaced to where we know the bonnet
comes to. And so now we're going to trim them

962.text:
apart to separate them. We're going to be
using a jigsaw cutter to trim the two moulds

968.text:
and we're using a permagrit blade which is
a tungsten carbide blade in the jigsaw. With

990.text:
the mould fully trimmed it's now time to some
extent for the moment of truth and what we're

994.text:
going to do is separate the upper and lowers
moulds. So to do it we're going to be using

999.text:
a chisel and trying to insert it between the
two layers of gel coat and then just tapping

1005.text:
that in with a hammer, I think we can hear
the moulds releasing. So we're just going

1011.text:
to insert lollypop sticks now. That's sounding
good. So that's our upper bonnet moulding

1038.text:
done now and it's just time to remove the
bonnet itself from this lower tool. We'll

1052.text:
be looking at doing this underside moulding
first because it's actually slightly more

1057.text:
complicated than the upper moulding. So the
first things that we'll do are pretty self

1060.text:
explanatory we'll strip off any of the filleting
wax that's on the underside of the moulding.

1066.text:
We'll also be looking at taking off any of
the release tape. And finally if there's any

1072.text:
blemishes such as this one here then we'll
just be filling some gel into those areas.

1079.text:
You'll fine that a chemical mould cleaner
like this will quickly and easily strip off

1086.text:
the filleting wax and any other contamination
from the mould surface. So this area that

1093.text:
you can see here, I think the paint actually
wrinkled up on the underside of the bonnet

1099.text:
and it's left this blemish here so what we're
going to do is chisel out all of the paint

1104.text:
and some of the gel coat so that we've got
some fresh material and then we're going to

1109.text:
put some new tooling gel coat into this blemished
area and sand it smooth. So to make a repair

1119.text:
like this what we do is we mix up just a small
amount of the Uni-Mould tooling gel coat a

1126.text:
few drops of wax additive and the wax additive
prevents the gel coat from staying tacky on

1134.text:
the surface where it comes into contact with
air like a gel coat would normally do. Once

1140.text:
the gel coat has hardened up and you can see
that the wax additive that we included has

1146.text:
meant that there's no tackiness here then
we can start wet sanding and flatting. So

1157.text:
we've flatted this out nicely now using the
wet and dry paper, we're just finishing it

1161.text:
off with a 1200 grit before we go on and use
polishing compound which we can either apply

1167.text:
by hand or as we're going to do using a polishing
wheel. Although both of these tools are now

1184.text:
pretty much ready to use as they are to give
this a real professional finish what we're

1189.text:
going to do on this top mould is give this
a wet flat all over with a 1200 grit and then

1195.text:
we're going to polish it all over using an
intermediate polishing compound like this

1201.text:
Mirka T10. The reason for wanting to give
it that flat on the surface is if you just

1206.text:
catch the reflection here of the light you
can just see a very very slightly texture

1211.text:
to the surface and that's partly print through
from the chopped strand mat underneath and

1216.text:
other just surface imperfections on the original
bonnet. We've now polished both of these moulds

1245.text:
up to a high standard and so that actually
concludes the fist part in this video series.

1250.text:
In the next instalment we're going to be looking
at using both of these moulds to produce the

1254.text:
parts themselves using the resin infusion
process. I really hope that you've enjoyed

1260.text:
this video. For more information or to purchase
any of the products that we've used in this

1264.text: video please visit our website easycomposites.co.uk.
